entry.title: 5 pontos essenciais para o fechamento da fase REALIZE em projetos SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
entry.content:
A fase REALIZE, dentro da metodologia SAP Activate, √© o momento em que tudo o que foi definido at√© aqui ganha vida: configura√ß√µes s√£o implementadas, extens√µes desenvolvidas, integra√ß√µes validadas e testes executados.
O bom fechamento desta fase garante que o projeto chegue ao DEPLOY de forma est√°vel, com riscos controlados e stakeholders confiantes.

O Roadmap da metodologia SAP Activate apresenta informa√ß√µes bem completas para apoio nesse momento. Mas caso precise de um guia para refer√™ncia r√°pida, deixo abaixo os 5 pontos chave que devem ser considerados neste momento. Como mais refer√™ncias, deixo ao final deste post o link para o Roadmap completo.

A seguir, compartilho os 5 pontos-chave que devem ser observados no encerramento do REALIZE:

1. Configura√ß√µes e Extens√µes Conclu√≠das

Todos os objetos de configura√ß√£o e extens√µes (incluindo in-app e side-by-side) devem estar conclu√≠dos e documentados.

  • Escopo implementado de acordo com o backlog aprovado

  • Customiza√ß√µes testadas e validadas

  • Documenta√ß√£o funcional e t√©cnica atualizada

Sem essa confirma√ß√£o, o cutover e os testes finais ficam comprometidos.

2. Integra√ß√µes Testadas e Estabilizadas

O REALIZE deve encerrar com as integra√ß√µes j√° validadas.

  • Interfaces cr√≠ticas funcionando de ponta a ponta

  • Conectividade e performance validadas

  • Monitoramento b√°sico configurado

Isso reduz riscos de falhas sist√™micas no DEPLOY.

3. Testes de Neg√≥cio Conclu√≠dos (UAT)

Os User Acceptance Tests (UAT) s√£o a valida√ß√£o final do neg√≥cio nesta fase.

  • Cen√°rios cr√≠ticos executados com aprova√ß√£o formal dos Key Users

  • Defeitos cr√≠ticos resolvidos ou com plano de corre√ß√£o definido

  • Evid√™ncias registradas para auditoria e governan√ßa

Avan√ßar sem um UAT conclu√≠do gera inseguran√ßa na virada produtiva.

4. Estrat√©gia e Execu√ß√£o de Migra√ß√£o de Dados

A fase REALIZE deve encerrar com a estrat√©gia de dados j√° validada e ciclos de migra√ß√£o testados.

  • Mock loads realizados com taxas de sucesso aceit√°veis

  • Regras de qualidade confirmadas

  • Respons√°veis e janelas de execu√ß√£o do cutover definidos

Esse ponto √© cr√≠tico: falhas de dados s√£o um dos maiores riscos de um Go-Live.

5. Riscos, Governan√ßa e Plano de Cutover Formalizados

Por fim, deve-se garantir que a transi√ß√£o ao DEPLOY esteja estruturada.

  • Riscos atualizados no risk register

  • Plano de cutover documentado e aprovado

  • Governan√ßa pronta para tomada de decis√£o r√°pida na virada

Isso d√° seguran√ßa para todos os stakeholders de que o projeto est√° pronto para a √∫ltima etapa.

Conclus√£o

Encerrar bem o REALIZE significa ter: configura√ß√µes conclu√≠das, integra√ß√µes testadas, UAT aprovado, dados validados e cutover planejado.
Com isso, o projeto segue para o DEPLOY com estabilidade, reduzindo riscos e garantindo confian√ßa da lideran√ßa.

O resultado? Um Go-Live muito mais seguro e previs√≠vel, com o valor de neg√≥cio do SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition pronto para ser entregue.

Link para o Roadmap SAP Activate relacionado a esta etapa:

https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer/group/658F507A-D6F5-4B78-9EE1-0300C5F1E40F/roadmapcontentpage/a11ec6d657054bf9:FA163EAF25B21EEB8FC47DE9E728C8DB

entry.title: Re: MD01N Behavior: Provision Stock at Subcontractor Loca...
entry.content:
Good day @Manohar_Rm 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at MRP Area Subcontractor , Subcontracting Without Source Location & ME2ON ‚Äì Subcontracting for more details.

To summarise, in MD01N, subcontracting stock at vendor is not treated as unrestricted-use stock at plant level. Therefore, when you do not define subcontractor MRP areas, the MRP ignores this stock and generates additional purchase requisitions. This is a common behaviour.

However, there are ways to resolve that situation:

  • First is for you to set up subcontractor MRP areas. Only after that does MRP consider vendor stock as available for covering subcontracting requirements.
  • If you do not consider MRP areas as an option, there is no standard way to force MD01N to treat subcontractor stock as unrestricted. In that case, you would need to either:
    • Need to manually monitor subcontractor stock,
    • a process redesign, or
    • a build a custom enhancement which is only possible in on-prem/private cloud.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

The information related to special taxes (Tobaco) is not directly in FI and customers may use different ways to calculate this (SAP Excise Tax manager , directly via pricing conditions in MM/SD, external systems...)  Customers with transactions subject to the these special taxes can use method SET_OUTPUT_DATA of BAdI EDOC_ADAPTOR to fill these fields.

Regards

entry.title: 5 Essential Points for Successfully Closing REALIZE in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects
entry.content:
The REALIZE phase in the SAP Activate methodology is where everything defined so far comes to life: system configuration, extensions, integrations, data migration cycles, and business testing.

Closing this phase properly ensures the project enters DEPLOY in a stable, controlled way, with stakeholders confident in the Go-Live readiness.

The SAP Activate Methodology Roadmap provides comprehensive information to support this stage. However, if you need a quick reference guide, below are the 5 key points that should be considered at this moment. For additional references, I‚Äôve included at the end of this post the link to the full Roadmap.

1. Completed Configurations and Extensions

All system configurations and required extensions (in-app and side-by-side) must be finalized and documented.

  • Scope implemented according to the approved backlog

  • Custom developments tested and validated

  • Updated functional and technical documentation

Without this confirmation, the cutover and final tests become highly risky.

2. Stabilized and Tested Integrations

REALIZE should close with end-to-end integrations validated and running.

  • Critical interfaces tested with positive results

  • Connectivity and performance verified

  • Monitoring in place for key scenarios

This reduces the risk of systemic failures during DEPLOY.

3. Business Testing (UAT) Completed

The User Acceptance Tests (UAT) are the ultimate business validation in REALIZE.

  • Critical business scenarios executed with formal sign-off by Key Users

  • Critical defects resolved or mitigation plan in place

  • Test evidence documented for audit and governance purposes

Proceeding without UAT completion compromises confidence in the Go-Live.

4. Data Migration Strategy Executed and Validated

The REALIZE phase must close with a validated data migration strategy and tested mock loads.

  • Trial migration cycles executed with acceptable success rates

  • Data quality rules confirmed

  • Ownership and cutover windows defined

Data issues are among the highest risks during Go-Live; preparation here is critical.

5. Risk Register, Governance, and Cutover Plan Formalized

Finally, the project must ensure a structured transition into DEPLOY.

  • Risk register updated with mitigation strategies

  • Cutover plan documented and approved

  • Governance ready to support fast decision-making during cutover

Conclusion

Closing the REALIZE phase means having: completed configurations, stabilized integrations, approved UAT, validated data migration, and a formalized cutover plan.
With these elements in place, the project can confidently move into DEPLOY with reduced risks and increased trust from leadership.

The outcome? A Go-Live that is more predictable, stable, and aligned to business value with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Link to the SAP Activate Roadmap related to this phase:

https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer/group/658F507A-D6F5-4B78-9EE1-0300C5F1E40F/roadmapcontentpage/a11ec6d657054bf9:FA163EAF25B21EEB8FC47DE9E728C8DB

entry.title: Everyday issues: SAP HANA database parameters (recommended by SAP) not configured properly.
entry.content:
• Why was this blog post created?
  • How to check/detect if SAP HANA parameters are set incorrectly?
  • What is the conclusion?
  • Everyday issues
  • Other article
  • Useful bookmark
  • Do you have further questions?
  • Contribution

last updated: 2025-10-01

Why was this blog post created?

Many times, deeper investigations are performed, for example, regarding general performance errors, without the basic SAP HANA parameters being set correctly. Inadequate parameter settings can be responsible for various severe issues. First of all, it is necessary to set the parameters correctly. Without these, the system will most likely not function optimally. 

Do not perform deep analysis until the SAP HANA recommended parameters are properly configured. Many times, setting these parameters correctly will solve some (or even all) problems on its own.

How to check/detect if SAP HANA parameters are set incorrectly?

1. 2903141 - Best practice configuration checks for SAP HANA

With the help of the HANA_Configuration_Parameters report these parameters can be checked easily.

2. 3409480 - The importance of proper tracking and maintenance of parameters in SAP HANA environments

The SAP Knowledge Base Articles contains all relevant information to properly maintain these parameters.

What is the conclusion?

In the absence of parameters belonging to the SAP HANA database, which is highly recommended by SAP, it is not worth performing any further investigation (belongs to performance, memory, etc.). This is a basic and primary step, and this parameter check must be performed not only after installation but also after a version update.

Everyday issues

‚úçÔ∏è Everyday issues: Unmanaged SAP HANA database backup.
‚úçÔ∏è Everyday issues: There is no miracle or magic. SAP HANA database needs memory.

Other article

‚úçÔ∏è Where can I find knowledge and information belongs to SAP HANA?
‚úçÔ∏è Where can I find information about the available tools for SAP HANA (all types of use)?

Useful bookmark

üîñ 2872774 ‚Äì Bookmark of Frequently Asked Questions for SAP HANA
üîñ 3311408 ‚Äì Bookmark of SQL Statement Collection reports for SAP HANA
üîñ 2658020 ‚Äì List of SAP HANA SQL Error Codes

Do you have further questions?

Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have question or observation regarding the article.
Q&A link for SAP HANA: https://answers.sap.com/tags/73554900100700000996 

Contribution

If you find any missing information belongs to the topic, please let me know. I am happy to add the new content. My intention is to maintain the content continuously to keep the info up-to-date.

Release Information

Release DateDescription
2025.10.01First/initial Release of the SAP Blog Post documentation (Technical Article).

entry.title: SAP‚Äôs Commitment to Business Continuity that Protects what Matters
entry.content:
When people want to guard valuable items from their personal collections, they turn to protected places, such as banks, where they can rest safely, shielded from any unanticipated events. For centuries, individuals have entrusted institutions to safeguard what is most treasured by them, whether personal belongings or other assets. In the same fashion, SAP is dedicated to assisting customers protect their business value.

Disruptions can happen at any time. The difference stands in how well-prepared customers can be for these challenging periods. For example, Black Friday and Cyber Monday are the busiest shopping periods of the year for retailers. During these events, downtime or poor performance can cost millions in lost sales and customer trust, which could hamper core business operations.

Holiday Season Readiness Program

To support industries processes during these times, SAP enhanced the Holiday Season Readiness Program for Commerce Cloud customers. This joint initiative between Support, Engineering, and Cloud Operations ensured retailers were fully equipped with:

  • Introduction of a Preventative Care Model powered by AI and automation, using the Agentic AI framework to proactively detect and even resolve issues before they impacted customers.
  • Weekly health checks, 360¬∞ action plans, proactive cases, and a 24x7 global control room with real-time monitoring and on-site staffing.

SAP for Me

Aligned with our commitment to being a reliable partner, SAP for Me is evolving into a customer‚Äôs digital companion, in one of the most exciting innovations within SAP. It‚Äôs no longer just a portal; it‚Äôs becoming a central hub for transparency, guidance, and predictive insights. It holds:

  • AI-driven transparency - SAP for Me aggregates critical alerts, metrics, and insights across a customer‚Äôs entire SAP product portfolio. With the integration of Business AI, it now gives visibility into AI unit availability, consumption, and expirations, helping customers avoid surprises and plan proactively.
  • Proactive business assurance - Instead of waiting for a billing or system issue, SAP for Me provides real-time and predictive views into usage, health, and risks. For instance, customers can track consumption trends by product and feature, updated hourly, and receive early warnings when capacity is at risk.
  • Simplified control - All AI usage is linked to finance and legal statements, so customers get a single source of truth that connects technical consumption with business accountability. This prevents overspend, protects return on investment (ROI), and ensures contractual clarity.
  • Continuous innovation - SAP is expanding SAP for Me with embedded AI copilots and guided recommendations, so in the future, customers won‚Äôt just see metrics ‚Äî they‚Äôll get actionable guidance on how to optimize systems and safeguard value.

Ongoing support and maintenance are critical to sustaining business value with SAP systems. A successful go-live is just the starting point; systems need to remain secure, compliant, and optimized as business needs to evolve. With proactive monitoring, automation, and AI-driven insights, customers can prevent disruptions, reduce risk, and maintain high availability. In practice, this means lower operational costs, higher uptime, and continuous ROI over the entire lifecycle of their SAP investment.

Just as we expect care when trusting our valuables to others, SAP is committed to safeguarding business value, providing seamless experiences that protect decisive revenue and build sustained trust.

A special thanks to Keith Ho, Customer Engagement Lead, and Manoj Gupta, SAP experts who have contributed to this article.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q3-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I‚Äôm covering:

  • ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation
  • Manage Footprint Results ‚Äì Source Input Items
  • GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation
  • Onboarding Booster
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Customer Success Stories: KNAPP & Tyrolit
  • Upcoming Partner Webinars
  • Additional Information

 

ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation

Transportation can be a major contributor to Scope 3 emissions, yet calculating its impact has mostly been complex and manual. With the new ERP‚Äëcentric transport footprint calculation, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a capability that leverages your existing ERP master and transactional data to automate and scale transport emission calculations. This means you can move from spreadsheets and estimates to actual, auditable results that integrate seamlessly into both corporate and product carbon footprints.

Instead of building transport models from scratch, the solution now derives upstream and internal transport activities from Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Return to Supplier, and Goods Transfer data, and then calculates the footprint per activity, route, and leg. In practical terms, a transport activity is determined as the movement of specific products in given quantities between two locations under defined conditions. The system brings together master data, transaction details, and transport settings to identify source and target locations, the mode of transport, and whether goods move under ambient or temperature-controlled conditions. It then builds optimal transport routes via connection points such as airports, seaports, inland ports, and railway stations, before applying the relevant emission factors to calculate the footprint.

 

In the following, I‚Äôll briefly summarize the required process steps and introduce the new apps. For detailed information, see Calculating Transport Footprints Using Business Transactions.

To use the new approach, start with importing transport-relevant master data, so routing and distances work out-of-the-box. Products now carry a Custom Temperature Condition, and SAP provides a default mapping to Ambient. If you need temperature-controlled transport, create your own custom conditions and map them to the standard values (Ambient or Temperature-Controlled). Locations and Plants now support addresses and geo-coordinates, and Business Partners can be imported with Supplier and Carrier roles, including address data tied to supplier IDs.

Then you can configure your inventory scope and in Transport Details set the Data Source to Standard (Business Transactions). Newly created scopes default to Standard, while existing scopes remain on Classic until you switch them.

For maintaining transport connection points ‚Äì like seaports, inland ports, airports, railway stations ‚Äì go to the Manage Locations app, where you already find SAP-delivered content for seaports and airports to help kick-start sea and air routes.

Next, configure how goods typically move in your network with the new Manage Transport Settings app. Define haul types and distances ‚Äì short haul defaults to 1500 km and can be adapted ‚Äì and specify the primary mode of transport from supplier locations to one or all plants, optionally by product group. The same supplier-to-plant mode applies to returns back to the supplier. For internal logistics, create directional settings for movements between plants.

With settings in place, use the new Manage Transport Activities app to generate transport activities for your chosen scope and period from the ERP transactions. Once activities are clean, generate the corresponding routes and legs. In case of inconsistencies, the app guides you with messages helping you to resolve before calculation.

Emission factors for the different modes of transport are managed in the new Manage Transport Operation Footprints app, and you can maintain them in the UI directly or import via file.

Finally, run the transport calculation in the new Calculate Transport Footprints app and review results per activity, route, and leg.

In the Calculate Footprints app, the Data Readiness tab lists transport data as one of the data types. Transport is now a first-class citizen across the analytics experience. In organizational footprint inventories, transport data becomes mandatory whenever your scope uses Standard and transport-relevant value chain steps are enabled. Transport footprints are created as input items to products, if a carrier is specified, the corresponding business partner footprint is used as the utilized item, otherwise the input is shown as Unknown Carrier. You can see transport-related product and business partner items in the Manage Footprint Results app, and analyze Scope 3.4 emissions in depth in the Footprint Overview app.

A quick note on provisioning: The new apps require explicit role assignment, role names are case-sensitive, and write access requires both read and write roles. If you‚Äôre moving from the classic transport approach, reimport your enhanced master data for Plants, Business Partners, Products, and relevant Locations via file or API, then switch your inventory scopes to Standard (Business Transactions). Keep scopes on Classic if you plan to recalculate them using the classic transport apps. With these pieces in place, the new transport calculation streamlines data preparation, strengthens routing fidelity, and brings transport emissions seamlessly into your product and corporate footprint story.

 

Manage Footprint Results ‚Äì Source Input Items

For decarbonizing your company and products, it‚Äôs crucial to have full transparency into what‚Äôs actually driving emissions across the value chain. While total product footprints are useful, they often leave a critical question unanswered: Where exactly do these emissions come from? Without that level of granularity, it‚Äôs difficult to identify hotspots, prioritize reduction efforts, or make informed decisions that lead to real impact. To address this, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management now includes a new feature in the Manage Footprint Results app: Source Input Items. This enhancement gives you a detailed view into the specific inputs that contribute to a product‚Äôs environmental footprint ‚Äì enabling smarter, data-driven strategies for decarbonization.

 

Source input items represent the materials, energy, transport, and other resources used at the start of a process that result in emissions. With just a click on Generate, you can now explore these contributors for each footprint item (excluding items of type business partner, work in progress, production documents, and supplier). Note that source input items currently cannot yet be generated for calculation results involving cycles, this will be added in a future release.

The app provides you with various charts that instantly visualize emissions across lifecycle stages such as material acquisition, production, transport, and end-of-life treatment. These charts help you pinpoint the most emission-intensive stages and align your analysis with the GHG Protocol. You can also customize the view to match your specific reporting or decision-making needs. Below the chart, a consolidated table provides full transparency into each source input item.

With this enhancement, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management strengthens its role as an intuitive product fact sheet, empowering you to go beyond high-level metrics. You can now trace emissions to their source, understand their context, and take targeted action ‚Äì whether that means switching suppliers, optimizing logistics, or redesigning products. For all information, see Viewing the Footprint Results on SAP Help.

 

GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation

One of the recurring challenges in tracking greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is the complexity and scale of data collection. Sustainability teams often need to gather activity and spend data from various business units, geographies, or partner organizations. To address these hurdles, we now released the GHG Data Forms API. This new public API empowers you to extend and tailor the GHG data collection process far beyond the core application: External workflows, survey applications, or even mobile apps can now retrieve, maintain, and push data directly into the GHG Data Forms in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. By decentralizing and parallelizing how and where environmental data is gathered, you can drive faster, more automated, and more consistent emission data capture across your full operational or organizational boundary. For technical details and integration guidelines, refer to the official API documentation on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

One powerful example of leveraging this API is through SAP Build Process Automation. With SAP Build workflows, you can automate and streamline sustainability data collection across multiple locations. The process begins by triggering a workflow, either manually or on a scheduled basis, then retrieving all relevant business activities and locations from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management using the API. Through parallel subprocesses for each location, you can enable simultaneous data collection and significantly reduce cycle time. Business users receive customizable forms ‚Äì survey-style via SAP Build or ticket-style via SAP Task Center ‚Äì delivered directly to the right people based on responsibility rules, with built-in notifications and reminders to keep the process moving. Once data is submitted, it‚Äôs routed for approval, and after validation, posted back to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and included into the overall footprint calculation. This approach provides flexibility, scalability, and compliance, helping sustainability teams focus on insights rather than manual tasks.

 

 

Onboarding Booster

With the introduction of the Onboarding Booster, we‚Äôre speeding up the time required for setting up am SAP Sustainability Footprint Management tenant on SAP BTP. The entire onboarding can now be completed in about 10 to 15 minutes through a guided, automated process. The booster is integrated into the SAP BTP cockpit and walks you through the essential steps: checking prerequisites, selecting the identity service, and either creating or choosing a subaccount. Once these steps are confirmed, the system takes over and performs the necessary configurations in the background. The result is a fully prepared environment that is ready for role assignment and productive use. This is more than just a time saver, it reduces complexity and lowers the barrier for customers to get started quickly and confidently. For detailed guidance, the full procedure is documented in our Help Portal: Setting Up Using Booster.

 

Other Release Highlights

We‚Äôve redesigned the SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure for a more intuitive experience. New app groups offer logical organization, simplifying navigation and helping you to quickly find what you need. For more information, see Enhanced SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure.

You can now assign different location types (not just plants) to a single business activity, expanding flexibility, supporting more accurate form generation, and ensuring that business activities can be valid across multiple locations. See Creating Business Activities for more information.

Additionally, when setting your footprint inventory scope, plant assignments now ensure that only relevant forms are generated for your selected companies and locations. This prevents the creation of irrelevant forms, enhancing efficiency and streamlining the data collection process. Learn more here: Creating Business Activities.

 

Customer Success Stories

KNAPP AG, a global leader in intralogistics and warehouse automation, faced new challenges with the EU‚Äôs Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which raised the bar for ESG transparency. Instead of waiting for deadlines, KNAPP acted early, building a strong sustainability data foundation with SAP Sustainability solutions. Partnering with KPMG Austria, KNAPP implemented SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower to replace manual reporting with automated, integrated processes. These solutions consolidated over 200 sustainability metrics from across the business, delivering advanced carbon footprint calculations at both product and corporate levels. This gave KNAPP unprecedented visibility into emissions, resource use, and overall ESG impact. With audit-ready reporting in place, KNAPP achieved CSRD compliance well ahead of schedule and embedded sustainability insights into daily operations and strategic planning. This proactive approach turned compliance into a catalyst for transformation, accelerating their ‚Äúnow4tomorrow‚Äù program and ensuring their first sustainability report complements financial disclosures. Read the full story: Getting ahead of regulatory reporting to steer business process transformation.

Tyrolit is a global leader in abrasive tools and construction systems that operates across 48 companies and exports to 140+ countries. Also facing growing demands for transparent ESG reporting under CSRD, Tyrolit needed to move beyond fragmented systems and spreadsheets that made standardization and auditability difficult. To address this, Tyrolit deployed SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower, integrated via SAP Business Technology Platform. This centralized ESG data collection from SAP and third-party systems, aligned sustainability reporting with financial standards, and enabled advanced analytics for benchmarking and target setting. AI-powered automation reduced manual work, improved accuracy, and provided dashboards for 60+ managers to monitor 80+ ESG metrics. This resulted in measurable carbon reductions, less plastic packaging, and higher recycling rates. Tyrolit now uses data-driven insights to identify emission-saving opportunities and embed sustainability across the organization. Check the full story: Tooling up to unlock the sustainable value chain with a robust ESG data foundation.

 

Upcoming Partner Webinars

Staying ahead means staying informed, and this quarter again brings two opportunities exclusively for our partners to connect and learn more about SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Both webinars are free for partners with a valid SAP Learning Hub license.

The SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training is a biannual event designed to empower partners with in-depth product know-how, practical guidance, and the latest innovations across SAP Cloud ERP, the SAP Business Suite, AI-powered features, and more. On October 10, you can learn more about the latest updates in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange. Register for the session here: Sustainability Management and Carbon Accounting. For an overview of all sessions and their respective registration links check out: SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training 2025.

On November 5, the Meet the Expert Session returns. This highly interactive webinar is your chance to bring questions directly to the SAP experts from the Product Management and Customer Adoption teams. Gain practical insights, obtain answers to your questions, and deepen your expertise in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Register here: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management - Meet the Expert Q4 2025.

 

Additional Information

To learn more on how you can enhance the accuracy of your Scope 3.1 emissions reporting by transitioning from broad average data to precise, supplier-specific actuals, you should check out the blog post Implementing an Average to Actuals Strategy for Scope 3.1 by @CButzlaff. This article outlines a practical, phased approach for implementing this strategy using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange.

For a comprehensive guide on how to embed carbon accounting into your ERP and finance processes, have a look into the new SAP PRESS book Carbon Accounting for Sustainability with SAP. It explains how to capture sustainability data across your ERP landscape, calculate product- and company-level carbon footprints, and integrate results into finance through SAP Green Ledger. You‚Äôll also learn how SAP Sustainability Data Exchange and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management enable accurate, auditable carbon data for decision-making and reporting.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What‚Äôs New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You‚Äôll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I‚Äôll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product‚Äôs new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I‚Äôm also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
entry.content:
Intro

Outbound interfaces are the lifeline between your new S/4HANA Greenfield or Selective Data Transition system and the outside world. Customers, vendors, 3PL partners, they still expect the same EDI (or non-EDI) output messages, even if you‚Äôve reshaped half your internal processes in the course of the SAP S/4HANA transformation.  

The real challenge? Functional consultants need to validate those outbound messages themselves, without waiting on an EDI provider, an integration colleague, or an EDI partner. That‚Äôs where Agentic AI validation with Int4 Suite comes in.

This playbook shows how functional consultants can independently test and validate outbound interfaces, step by step, without leaving the SAP S/4HANA + Int4 Suite environment.

Why functional consultants, not integration teams?

Most SAP projects (Greenfield, Selective Data Transition, or any other complex SAP S/4HANA upgrades) involve huge shifts inside SAP, but the outside world doesn‚Äôt care. Partner EDI flows must remain identical.

Traditionally, testing those flows meant:

  • Asking the EDI partner/provider for some sample messages
  • Trying to run the transaction in SAP S/4HANA
  • Asking the EDI provider to re-check/confirm outbound messages.
  • Pulling in a specialist from the integration team if something takes too long.
  • Repeating the same process multiple times with very little time to do it

Our approach flips this. It empowers the SAP functional consultant to:

  • Insert thousand of historical EDI messages from any productive system
  • Ask Int4 Suite to find the test data within those messages
  • Reproduce SAP transactions from historical payloads, like Sales Order Confirmation, Delivery (ASN) notification, Invoice Notification
  • Validate the EDI outbound messages directly in Int4 Suite by the functional consultant
  • The whole process takes minutes not hours and can be done hundreds of times per hour with no external dependencies (other partners)

No waiting on specialists, no bottlenecks, and much faster iterations.

Step 1: Reality-first message mining with Robotic Crawler

Use the Int4 Robotic Crawler to load hundreds or thousands of real historical messages (EDI or otherwise) into Int4 Suite. These are not toy examples ‚Äî they‚Äôre your actual outbound payloads as they once moved through production.

Figure - Int4 Suite Robotic Crawler can fetch EDI messages from any supported archive or integration platform on mass scale 

Why it matters: Consultants can work with authentic data, not spec sheets or made-up test cases.

Step 2: Conversational selection of test cases

Functional consultants don‚Äôt need to master payload filtering. Instead, they can simply chat with the agent to select which messages they want to test.

Want to see all outbound orders from a specific customer? Or deliveries with a particular Incoterm? Just ask the agent.

Figure - select a historical EDI messages using different criteria (business document, partner, material, etc.) and use this data for testing 

Why it matters: Test-case discovery becomes intuitive, not a technical exercise.

Step 3: Reconstruct SAP business objects from payloads

Once a message is selected, the consultant can instantly recreate a business document (e.g., a Sales Order) inside S/4HANA using the data from that outbound message.

Figure - creating a sales order using the data from the historical EDI message as input 

Now you have a living document in S/4HANA, built directly from the same payload your partners receive.

Why it matters: Consultants can validate the end-to-end logic of their own functional processes, with no dependency on integration experts.

Step 4: Agentic comparison of original vs. new outbound message

After posting the new Sales Order (or Delivery, or Invoice), the consultant sends the newly generated outbound reference back to the AI agent. The agent compares this outbound message to the original one from Step 1.

Figure - use the historical EDI message to compare with the new one and fetch is by just supplying the new order reference number 

Are they still identical? Has anything in S/4HANA configuration changed the outbound structure? Did the partner-facing fields remain untouched?

Figure - display the comparison of the two EDI messages (original and the new one) to fix any SAP S/4HANA configuration issues (like line item category determination, substitutions, calculations, etc.) 

Why it matters: Consultants get a precise answer immediately, without needing to export messages into external systems or call for backup.

Who benefits from this approach?

  • Functional consultants in SAP S/4HANA Greenfield or Selective Data Transition projects who must ensure message stability despite deep process changes.
  • Project teams that want faster, independent validation without pulling scarce EDI resources.
  • Business stakeholders who need assurance that partners will keep receiving the same documents as before, no surprises.

Who is this not for?

  • Integration consultants looking to stress-test iFlows or middleware mappings ‚Äî this isn‚Äôt their playground. Int4 Suite has other features to facilite those requirements.
  • EDI providers who validate full partner connectivity, that‚Äôs still their domain.
  • Pure developers focused on code-level regression, this approach is tailored for business-facing validation.

Why it matters for S/4HANA programs where EDI messages remain the same but SAP S/4HANA can change? 

Outbound interfaces are always the fragile bridge in any migration. By equipping functional consultants with agentic AI validation, you:

  • Shorten test cycles.
  • Reduce reliance on external partners.
  • Increase confidence in project quality.

Outbound messages stay consistent, partners stay happy, and your SAP S/4HANA Greenfield program keeps its velocity.

This approach isn‚Äôt about replacing integration experts ‚Äî it‚Äôs about freeing functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves the system is still what the outside world expects. It‚Äôs the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction interface validation in SAP transformations.

entry.title: Japan Bank Charges in Payment Lots
entry.content:
This blog post introduces the procedure of payments with the bank charges in a payment lot in Contract Accounting. This function is currently available for SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

According to the contract, you are the contract partner providing the goods or services and covering the bank charges. This blog post introduces customizing activities and how they influence payment processing.

Master Data Settings

In the contract account level, you set up the cost allocation key and the instruction key.

  1. Open the contract account master date in the transaction CAA1 (Create) or transaction CAA2 (Edit).
  2. In the Cross-Country tab, enter the cost allocation key.
    To use the functionality on the Contract account level, you must select value "2- Charges payable by payee " in the Cost allocation key field.

Customizing Activities

Activating the Business Function ‚Äì FICA_LOC_JP1

You must activate the business function to use the functions for Japan bank charges in Contract Accounting.

Activating Japan Bank Charge for Company Code

After you activated the business function in your system, you can switch on the Japan bank charges feature for specific company codes.

  1. In the Set Up Company Codes for Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable activity (view: TFK001B).
  2. Double click the entry of the company code.
  3. In the Country/Region-specific Functions select the Activate Settings for JP (Bank Charges) checkbox.

Activating Bank Charge for Document Type

In this activity, you activate bank charges for payment runs.

  1. In the Activate Bank Charges activity (view: V_TFK_JP_BCH).
  2. Enter an entry for the payment run.
    Sample value:
Application AreaCompany CodeHouse BankCurrencyDocument Origin
C ‚Äì Convergent FI-CA<Your company code><Your company code>JPY06 - Payment run
Determining accounts for bank charges

In this activity you post attributes assignment to include a tax determination for bank charge.

  1. In the transaction FQC0, enter 1111 in the posting area field and the Chart of accounts.
  2. Assign a G/L account and tax determination.

Maintaining Tolerance Groups

In this activity you maintain the tolerance groups which can be assigned on the Contract account level. When the received payment is less than the amount of the open item, and the shortage of the money is within the tolerance group, the system can still clear the open item.

In this activity you can either set up an absolute amount or a percentage from a payment amount to calculate the tolerance. If you set up both absolute amount and percentage as tolerance, the system calculates and chooses the lower tolerance amount to use.
This activity is a prerequisite for setting threshold for the amount difference as bank charges.

  1. In the transaction SM30, enter the customizing table TFK043.
  2. Create or select a tolerance group entry.

Setting Thresholds for the Amount Difference as Bank Charges

In this activity you can either set up an absolute amount or a percentage from a payment amount to calculate the threshold. If you set up both absolute amount and percentage as thresholds, the system calculates and chooses the lower threshold amount to use.

  1. Open the V_TFK_JP_BCHTH view in the transaction SM30.
  2. Set the thresholds with absolute amount or percentage, or both for bank charges.
    You can select the "deactivation" checkbox to avoid calculating bank charges for the tolerance group and currency. By doing so, the item relevant to bank charges is not posted in the G/L account.

Bank Charge Calculation

In the following paragraph we look at the how the tolerance group setting, and the threshold settings can work together:

Example 1-

You set up the tolerance group as follows:

  • Tolerance expense absolute value = 500
  • Tolerance expense percentage value = 10%

You set up the threshold for Japan bank charges in the V_TFK_JP_BCHTH view.

  • Tolerance group is as the settings above.
  • Threshold absolute value: 215
  • Threshold percentage value: 2%

The following graphic shows the range of the difference between the payment and the open item amount, hereinafter referred to as difference.

Absolute Values

Case 1: When the difference is > 0 but < 215, the difference is considered as SAP standard tolerance. Corresponding postings are completed based on the SAP standard settings for tolerance within clearing document.

Case 2: When the difference is >=215 but <= 500, the difference is considered as Japan bank charge. Corresponding postings are completed based on the Japan localization settings within clearing document.

Examples of the Absolute Values:

Open item amount

Payment

Difference

Threshold (Absolut Amount)

Posting of clearing document

Note

10800

10600

10800 ‚Äì 10600 = 200

215

Tolerance posting (case 1)

Difference is less than threshold absolute and the tolerance expense absolute.

10800

10500

10800- 10500 = 300

215

Japan bank charge (case 2)

Difference is higher than the threshold absolute and less than the tolerance expense absolute.

10800

10000

10800 ‚Äì 10000 = 800

215

Payment to be clarified (clarification list), or Payment on account, or Clearing document not created (when online processing within the clarification list)

Difference is higher than the threshold absolute and the tolerance expense absolute.

Percentage Values

Case 3: When the difference is > 0 but from the total amount of open items to be cleared, the difference is considered as the SAP standard tolerance. Corresponding postings are completed based on the SAP standard settings for tolerance within clearing document.

Case 4: When the difference is but is <= 10% from the total amount of open items to be cleared, the difference is considered as a Japan bank charge. Corresponding postings are completed based on the Japan localization settings within clearing document.

Example of Percentage Values

The threshold amount with percentage is calculated as follows:  

Threshold amount (percentage values) = Open item amount / 100 * 2 %  

Open item amount

Payment

Difference

Threshold

Posting of clearing document

Note

10800

10600

10800 ‚Äì 10600 = 200

10800/100*2% = 216

Tolerance posting (Case 3)

Difference is less than the threshold absolute and the tolerance expense absolute.

10800

10500

10800- 10500 = 300

10800/100*2% = 216

Japan bank charge (Case 4)

Difference is higher than the threshold absolute and the tolerance expense absolute.

10800

10000

10800 ‚Äì 10000 = 800

10800/100*2% = 216

Payment to be clarified (clarification list) or

Payment on account, or

Clearing document not created (when online processing within the clarification list)

Difference is higher than both the threshold absolute and the tolerance expense absolute.

If you set up both the threshold absolute value and the threshold percentage value, the system takes the lower threshold amount for calculation.

Defining Clearing Category

This activity defines Clearing categories which can be assigned on the Contract account level, and determines how the system manage and clear open items during clearing.

  1. Open the TFK111 view in the transaction SM30.
  2. Create Clearing category for Japan.

Defining Clearing Variants

This activity defines the rules and steps for clearing open items in Financial Contract Accounting. It controls how the system selects, groups, sorts, and assigns amounts to items during clearing.

  1. Open the V_TFK110 view in the transaction SM30.
  2. Select the clearing variant for Japan.
  3. Make setting in the clearing steps.
    In the Group rule, select the 3 - Amount rule and select the Write-off Tolerance checkbox.

Defining Defaults for Incoming Payments

This activity is used when the incoming payment amount is smaller than the amount of clearing the open receivable item and you want to use it for specific Clearing category. . The amount difference between them is the bank charge.

  1. Open the VC_TFK113_1 view in transaction SM30.
  2. For the incoming payment specification, select 05- Payment Lot.
  3. For the Alternative clearing variant, select the Clearing category and Clearing variant that you have defined in the previous customizing activity.

Cash Discount and Payment Differences

You have completed the determining accounts for bank charges activity. This activity is SAP standard functionality for tolerance, which includes tolerance account settings and tolerance posting.

  1. In the transaction FQC0 enter the posting area 0060.
  2. Enter the Chart of accounts and define accounts.

Define clarification account for incoming payments

In this activity you determine a accounts for posting a payment on account.

  1. In the transaction FQC0 enter the posting area 1040.
  2. Enter the Chart of accounts and define the account.

Procedure of Processing Payments in Payment Lot

We categorize three scenarios based on the difference:

  1. Difference between the incoming payments and open items falls in the tolerance posting ‚Äì tolerance posting
  2. Difference between the incoming payments and open items falls in the bank charges ‚Äì bank charge posting
  3. Difference between the incoming payments and open items falls beyond the tolerance group setting ‚Äì postprocessing payments in the clarification payment lot

We take the threshold absolute amount as 215 JPY and the tolerance group setting as 500 JPY.

Case 1- Tolerance posting

  1. You post receivable documents. The open contract accounting document amount is 21,600 JPY.
  2. Your bank gets the payment with the amount 21,500 JPY from the customer, which is short of 100 JPY. In the graphic as below, the difference falls below the threshold absolute amount and is taken as a tolerance posting.
  3. You then create payment lots in the transaction FP05 for processing incoming payments.
  4. You clear the outgoing invoice with the full amount of the open items and post a new line items in the general ledger account for Japan bank charge.

Case 2- Posting Bank Charges

  1. You post documents in transaction FPE1. The open invoice amount is 21,600 JPY (as case 1).
  2. Your bank gets the payment with the amount 21,200 JPY from the customer, which is short of 400 JPY. In the graphic as below, the difference falls below the tolerance group setting but higher than the threshold absolute amount and a bank charge is posted to G/L account.
  3. You then create payment lots in the transaction FP05 for processing incoming payments.
    In the G/L items, the bank charges are listed together with the tax amount.
  4. You clear the outgoing invoice with the full amount of the open items and post a new line items in the general ledger account for Japan bank charge.

Case 3 ‚Äì Postprocessing Payments

  1. You post documents in transaction FPE1. The open invoice amount is 21,600 JPY (as case 1).
  2. Your bank gets the payment with the amount 21,000 JPY from the customer, which is short of 600 JPY. In the graphic as below, the difference falls beyond the tolerance group settings.
  3. You then create payment lots in the transaction FP05, however, posting of clearing of open item is not possible because the difference is higher than permitted tolerance limit. You then see ‚Äúpostprocessing is required‚Äù in the status.
  4. Go to the Clarification Payment Lot (transaction: FPCPL) and specify the selection screen.
    Then select the item you want to process, and choose Clarify.

    You can then post a document, transfer a document, or request repayment.

Reference

To learn more about the relevant topics, see the blog post - Japan Bank Charges in Payment Runs.

See the related SAP Notes:

  • 3551142 - Contract Account Enhancements in Contract Accounting (FI-CA)
  • 3551216 - Japan: Payment Processing with Bank Charges in Contract Accounting

entry.title: Re: Handling Unit in Transfer Stock Cross Plant
entry.content:
Please note in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud environment, handling units (HUs) are not preserved during cross-plant stock transfers when both the issuing and receiving storage locations are WM managed.

Key Points:

  • The HU sent from the issuing plant is not retained as-is in the receiving plant.
  • This behavior is due to scope limitations in the public cloud WM functionality.
  • As a result, the system does not support HU continuity across WM-managed locations in standard cross-plant transfer processes.

SAP‚Äôs official documentation confirms this limitation: Transfer Stock - Cross-Plant

entry.title: Re: SAP Business One
entry.content:
@anthamy: "I don't know what the learning roadmap would be" That is the point. You need to first determine what part, in terms of purpose, of S/4 you are interested in and/or good at.

If I may make an analogy, think of it this way, if ERP is transport, then SAP Business is a complete lorry, and S/4 is anything that is related to flying, from drones to F16s to jumbojets, and HANA is fuel that can be put into anything. Do you want to fly a drone, an F16 or a Jumbojet, or do you just want to do maintenance of the airport? Depending on your answer the learning roadmap is completely different.

entry.title: Re: Manage Processing Rules - For Bank Statements
entry.content:
Hi @CGLIT ,

 

First of all, please make sure to follow the community rules.
You created a question with the title "Manage Processing Rules - For Bank Statements". This title is not meaningful and makes it difficult for others to understand your issue at a glance. Please use clear and descriptive titles so that community members can quickly see what your question is about.

Secondly, one question per thread.
Each thread should ideally address a single question. If you have multiple questions, please create separate threads. This makes it easier for others to find relevant answers later.

Now, regarding your questions:

  1. In your first screenshot, you show an AP/AR processing rule with ID 24. However, in the second screenshot, the application log shows that rule ID 25 was applied. Since we cannot see the details of rule 25, it‚Äôs not clear how it differs from rule 24. In other words, you are comparing two different rules (like apples to oranges). The rule shown in your screenshot is not the one that was actually applied to the bank statement item.

  2. For your second question: no, you do not need to take any manual action when you have set up an automatic processing rule. The rule handles everything for you‚Äîthis is exactly why it is called an automatic processing rule. This applies regardless of the action type you configure.

Tagging you for visibility as you answered as well @Anita_Ahmadpour 

 

Best,

Edrilan Berisha

entry.title: EDA with AEM and SAP Customer Activity Repository
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

we‚Äôre currently expanding our Event-Driven Architecture using SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) to connect more systems and data products.

Most integrations follow a standardized approach, which helps us keep things maintainable. One system we‚Äôre now looking at is SAP Customer Activity Repository (CAR) ‚Äì especially for event-based use cases like promotions and coupons.

We‚Äôve explored several options, but none of them seem to fit well into a clean, standard setup:

  • AIF for AEM doesn‚Äôt run on CAR due to missing S/4HANA core components.
  • ASAPIO isn‚Äôt supported on CAR.
  • SLT from CAR to S/4HANA to use AIF or ASAPIO there feels like a detour.
  • Custom BAPI-based REST calls are possible, but not really what we‚Äôre aiming for.

So here‚Äôs the question:

Is there a standard or recommended way to bring SAP CAR into an event-driven architecture‚Äîwithout relying on custom developments or indirect replication paths?

Would love to hear how others have approached this!

entry.title: Re: Alternative Unit of Measures for different products
entry.content:
To achieve your goal without deleting AUoMs, you should avoid using stock-specific UoM globally and instead rely on Preferred UoM per product in EWM. Here's how:

1. Remove Meter from Stock-Specific UoM

  • Do not maintain meter as a stock-specific UoM globally.
  • This avoids RFUI defaulting to meter for all materials with AUoM = meter.

2. Use Preferred UoM in EWM Product Master

  • Go to EWM Product Master (/SCWM/MAT1)
  • For Product A, set Preferred UoM = Pieces
  • For Product B, set Preferred UoM = Meters

This ensures RFUI proposes the correct UoM during putaway based on the material.

3. Ensure Conversion Ratios Are Accurate

  • Maintain proper conversion between BUoM and AUoM in the material master.
  • This allows EWM to calculate quantities correctly when switching between UoMs.

4. Avoid Global SUoM Settings

SUoM should be used only when all materials in a stock type are handled in the same AUoM ‚Äî which is not your case.

entry.title: SAP MDG: Validation - No Special Characters in Account Holder Field
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great üôÇ

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.

This post outlines a custom development approach in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to restrict the use of special characters in the Account Holder field. The validation logic is implemented using the enhancement framework via BADI: USMD_RULE_SERVICE, specifically through the method CHECK_ENTITY. This ensures data consistency and compliance with formatting standards during master data creation and change processes.

Prerequisite: A working knowledge of BADI USMD_RULE_SERVICE and ABAP development is required to follow this implementation.

Development Details

  • Message Class: ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS
  • Message Number: 002
  • Message Type: E
  • Message Text: The Account Holder field must not contain any special characters
  • BADI Method Implemented: IF_EX_USMD_RULE_SERVICE~CHECK_ENTITY 

    The validation logic is written directly in the method CHECK_ENTITY

    This ensures that when the Account Holder field is entered, the system validates the content to ensure it does not contain any special characters, and raises a custom message if invalid characters are found

Code:

 METHOD if_ex_usmd_rule_service~check_entity.
   DATA: lt_data        TYPE usmd_ts_data_entity,
         lt_bank_data   TYPE REF TO data,
         lt_msg         TYPE usmd_t_message,
         ls_msg         TYPE usmd_s_message,
         lv_fieldname   TYPE bu_koinh,
         lv_acc_holder TYPE char20.
   FIELD-SYMBOLS:
     <lt_bank>        TYPE SORTED TABLE,
     <ls_bank>        TYPE any,
     <lv_acc_holder> TYPE any.
   io_model->get_changed_fields(
     IMPORTING	
       et_entity_fieldname =  DATA(lt_fieldname)               
   )
   .
   LOOP AT lt_fieldname INTO DATA(ls_fieldname).
     lv_fieldname = ls_fieldname-fieldname.
     IF lv_fieldname = 'KOINH'.
       lv_acc_holder = lv_fieldname.
     ENDIF.
   ENDLOOP.
   IF lv_acc_holder = 'KOINH'.
     io_model->read_entity_data_all(
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname      =       'BP_HEADER'           " Financial MDM: Field Name
        if_active        =         abap_false          " Financial MDM: General Indicator
    i_crequest       =            id_crequest          " Change Request
      IMPORTING
    et_message       =        lt_msg          " Messages
        et_data_entity   =      lt_data            " Data for Entity Types
    ).
     lt_bank_data = VALUE #( lt_data[ usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_BKDTL' struct = 'KATTR' ]-r_t_data  OPTIONAL ).
     IF lt_bank_data IS NOT INITIAL.
       ASSIGN lt_bank_data->* TO <lt_bank>.
       IF <lt_bank> IS ASSIGNED.
         LOOP AT <lt_bank> ASSIGNING <ls_bank>.
           ASSIGN COMPONENT 'KOINH' OF STRUCTURE <ls_bank> TO <lv_acc_holder>.
           IF <lv_acc_holder> IS ASSIGNED AND
              <lv_acc_holder> IS NOT INITIAL AND                        
             <lv_acc_holder> CA '~`!@#$%^&*()-_+={}[]|\:;"<,>.?/'.
             et_message = VALUE #( BASE et_message ( fieldname = 'KOINH' msgid = 'ZMDGS_MESSAGE_CLS' msgno = '002' msgty = 'E' ) ).
           ENDIF.
         ENDLOOP.
       ENDIF.
     ENDIF.
   ENDIF.
 ENDMETHOD.

entry.title: From ABAP to the World: Daniel‚Äôs Journey of Growth and Resilienc
entry.content:
If you meet Daniel Mateo Perez outside work, you'll likely find him by the ocean. On Saturday mornings, he's barefoot on the beach with tea or planning his next trip‚Äîhe's visited over 60 countries. Travel shapes his curious, adaptable, and open perspective‚Äîtraits vital for SAP projects.

Daniel didn‚Äôt plan a career working with SAP technology. A Chemical Engineering graduate in Barcelona, he began his professional journey as an ABAP developer at a consulting firm. But he quickly realized his real passion was in connecting technology with business. A manager advised him: ‚ÄúIf you really want to grow, learn Finance and Logistics with SAP.‚Äù That moment changed everything.

His first SAP classroom training in Supply Chain Management sparked a powerful realization. ‚ÄúFor the first time, I saw how procurement, inventory, and finance all connected. It blew my mind‚Äîthis was the solution that runs companies.‚Äù That moment didn‚Äôt just build knowledge; it gave him a surge of confidence and set a clear direction for his professional journey.

Two decades later, SAP certifications have propelled his career and unlocked new opportunities. Today, he proudly holds SAP Activate Project Manager and SAP S/4HANA for Financial Accounting certifications and is already reaching higher, working toward more in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Each one, Daniel says, has been ‚Äúa credibility booster,‚Äù fueling his ongoing professional growth.

‚ÄúSAP Certifications gave me more than technical skills,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúThey gave me trust. With clients, with colleagues, and with myself. When you‚Äôre certified, people know you can deliver.‚Äù

That trust opened doors. Daniel has led multi-country SAP S/4HANA rollouts across various industries, including pharmaceuticals and media, co-authored a book on rollout strategies in Spanish, and mentored younger consultants as they navigate their careers. He‚Äôs also become known as the calm presence during stressful go-lives‚Äîsomeone who can translate between IT and finance and keep projects moving.

It hasn‚Äôt always been easy. Switching from development to finance consulting nearly made him quit. ‚ÄúI remember leaving a workshop convinced I‚Äôd never understand finance,‚Äù he admits. But curiosity‚Äîand the structure of SAP learning materials‚Äîkept him going. Step by step, SAP Certification by SAP Certification, he built both expertise and resilience.

Looking back, he says the biggest surprise is that SAP learning never ends. ‚ÄúAt first it felt overwhelming, but now I see it as the reason my career has stayed exciting.‚Äù

If he could give advice to his younger self‚Äîor anyone considering starting‚ÄîDaniel would keep it simple: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt wait until you feel ready. Nobody knows everything. Just start, get certified, and grow from there.‚Äù

From backpacking buses in Asia, where he studied for certifications, to global boardrooms where he delivers enterprise transformations, Daniel‚Äôs story showcases the real power of SAP Certification: it doesn‚Äôt just unlock opportunities‚Äîit gives you the confidence and credibility to walk through them.

Take your next step: visit the SAP Learning site, choose your certification, and start shaping your future today.

entry.title: Unlocking SAP Fiori and other business content on Mobile: A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Introduction: Accessing SAP business content on mobile

While analysing the recent search queries from users around ‚Äúthe use of SAP on mobile‚Äù we came across the below examples.

  • is there an app for SAP Fiori? 
  • can I access SAP Fiori from mobile? 
  • how to use SAP Fiori on iPhone? 
  • can SAP be used in mobile? 
  • how to open SAP on mobile? 
  • what SAP business content is available on mobile?

There were also questions around how SAP Mobile Start fit into the picture with the standard set of mobile apps for each of the cloud solutions from SAP; for e.g. SAP SuccessFactors mobile.

Providing clarity on these kinds of questions served as the motivation for writing this blog. We will also look at the broader set of business content that can be accessed from mobile as standard or via configuration.

Is SAP Fiori Client still relevant?

The SAP Fiori Client mobile app provided a native runtime environment for SAP Fiori apps on iOS and Android devices.  It was removed from the Apple App Store and Google Play Store on March 31st, 2022. (Refer to SAP Note 2992772).

While the above SAP note does recommend the users of SAP Fiori to transition to SAP Mobile Start, the above search queries gave the impression that customers probably could do with bit more guidance on the overall strategy and approach around accessing SAP business content including SAP Fiori apps from mobile.

Decision tree for alternatives to SAP Fiori Client

As mentioned in the SAP Note 2992772, one of the options is for the users of SAP Fiori Client to transition to SAP Mobile Start. Here‚Äôs a visual representation of the decision tree for customers who are still using SAP Fiori Client as covered in SAP Fiori Client successor recommendations.

Product positioning of SAP Mobile Start

SAP Mobile Start is positioned as the mobile native entry point for business applications, processes and business data from SAP and non-SAP solutions. SAP Mobile Start was initially released for iOS (iPhone and iPad) in September 2021 and the Android version was later released in June 2022. This also signified a change in mobile strategy for SAP by moving away from the hybrid world to native app approach.

 

The mobile app for SAP's central entry point solutions

SAP Mobile Start brings the content that is deployed on SAP‚Äôs central entry point solutions to mobile users.

 

Once the business content is deployed on these solutions, you can enable the power of mobile to the end-users with a QR code scan at almost no additional implementation effort or deploy using Mobile Device Management (MDM).

 

Accessing SAP business content from mobile

Now let‚Äôs dive deeper into how the following types of business content can be deployed and consumed via SAP Mobile Start.

  1. standard business content from SAP S/4HANA that is mobile enabled
  2. custom SAP Fiori apps created using SAP Build
  3. custom native apps created using SAP mobile services
  4. other SAP business solutions content

1. SAP S/4HANA standard business content on mobile

Let‚Äôs address the question on how to access SAP S/4HANA business content (SAP Fiori roles and apps) via mobile.

  • SAP Fiori Apps Reference library can provide a list of SAP Fiori apps that are optimized for mobile phone and tablet. For e.g. you can discover apps ‚Äúby Line of Business‚Äù; for e.g. Finance, Sourcing and Procurement etc.

 
  • You need to implement SAP Fiori roles and apps for your chosen processes on your SAP Fiori launchpad on SAP S/4HANA; refer to How to Deliver a Great User Experience with SAP S/4HANA.
  • You can then federate and bring the business content (SAP Fiori roles and apps) to one of the central entry point solutions mentioned above. Refer to the learning journey: Setting up SAP Mobile Start with SAP S/4HANA on SAP Build Work Zone which explains how to do this using SAP Build Work Zone and bring it to mobile.

You can also refer to below assets:

  • SAP Fiori Deployment Options and System Landscape Recommendations is the reference document for all consultants, partners and customers who implement SAP Fiori. Do note that it also mentions the use of SAP Build Work Zone as a central entry point deployment option.
  • SAP Fiori Deployment in 2025: Embedded vs. Work Zone Standard vs. Advanced Edition also gives some insights into comparing various deployment options.

2. Creating and consuming custom SAP Fiori apps

SAP Build is a unified application development and process automation solution, enabling personalization and efficiency at scale. You can create custom SAP Fiori apps, using SAP Build Apps (for low-code development) and SAP Build Code (for pro-code development). You can connect to your SAP S/4HANA or other backend system, use visual tools to define data models and UI elements, and leverage generative AI with tools like Joule to accelerate development.

SAP Build Work Zone can act as the central entry point to consume these custom apps as well as the federated (standard) business content from SAP S/4HANA. SAP Mobile Start can consume the content that is deployed on SAP Build Work Zone.

3. Creating custom mobile apps that follows SAP Fiori guidelines

Some customers may have use cases for which they might want to create custom native mobile applications that meets the following requirements:

  • utilize the native capabilities offered by the respective operating systems
  • while also following the SAP Fiori design guidelines
  • and maintaining the same user-experience as that of the business solutions from SAP.

This is where SAP Mobile Services comes into picture. It is an open standard based service on SAP Business Technology Platform that enables simple mobile application development, configuration, and management. It offers:

  • SAP Mobile Development kit which is a metadata driven tool that can allow you to develop cross platform applications.
  • Or SAP BTP SDKs for iOS as well as Android for those who want more flexibility beyond what the above metadata driven approach can provide.

These SDKs follow SAP Fiori design guidelines to preserve the familiarity of both the native operating system experience as well the SAP Fiori app experience; refer to SAP Fiori mobile design guidelines.

Any custom native app that you create can of course be launched from SAP Mobile Start via a native tile; refer to add native apps to your content.

4. Other SAP business solutions content

To be a true native entry point, SAP Mobile Start app also needs to bring the business content and key capabilities from other SAP business solutions to a mobile user.  Let's have a closer look at the possibilities.

  • SAP S/4HANA (as explained above)
    • mobile enabled apps from SAP S/4HANA SAP Fiori launchpad via content federation 
    • workflow notifications and situations
  • SAP Task Center integration for tasks; for e.g. Purchase Order approval from SAP S/4HANA. Also tasks from SAP Ariba , SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Cloud for Customer, SAP Concur, SAP Fieldglass, SAP Field Service Management, SAP Marketing Cloud, SAP Workflow Service, 3rd party providers
  • UI integration cards displaying Insights and custom cards
  • URL tile to Cloud solutions from SAP e.g. SAP Concur web
  • Analytical story from SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Native app tile to launch specialised app from the respective SAP Cloud solution
    • e.g. SAP Concur mobile
    • or deep links where SAP Cloud solution supports the same; e.g. using SAP SuccessFactors deep link to directly launch Compensation details
  • SAP Document AI integration

 

Big picture on SAP‚Äôs mobile portfolio

To complete the picture on SAP‚Äôs mobile portfolio, we must also talk about the dedicated mobile apps that comes with each of the cloud solutions from SAP ; for e.g. SAP SuccessFactors mobile, SAP Analytics Cloud mobile, SAP Concur mobile etc and how SAP Mobile Start fits into the picture.

SAP Mobile Start in the context of other SAP mobile apps

SAP Mobile Start is not intended to provide the ability for the end users to access all mobile enabled capabilities from all the cloud solutions from SAP. It is meant to be a native entry point from where the following can be done.

  • the most valuable capabilities and content from the business solutions can be accessed as described above.
  • and the specialised mobile apps provided by each of these cloud solutions from SAP can be launched.

 

Conclusion:

In summary

  • SAP Mobile Start is the mobile native entry point into SAP universe for a mobile user.
  • Administrators can deploy the most critical content from various business solutions from SAP as outlined above on SAP's central entry point solutions and bring them to SAP Mobile Start.
  • The end-users can further use the specialised standard SAP mobile apps.
  • SAP Mobile Services provides a choice of SAP BTP SDKs that can be used to create custom native apps when end-user needs go beyond the standard set of apps provided by SAP while also maintaining the familiarity of the respective operating system as well as SAP Fiori design guidelines.
  • The users of SAP Fiori Client are encouraged to move to SAP Mobile Start.

We look forward to hearing your experience with setting up these solutions in your landscape. We are keen to hear about mobile personas and use-cases you have taken advantage of. Please do share your thoughts and comments below.

Stay up to date with latest news and post your questions or feedback about SAP Mobile Start in the Q&A area. Start by visiting your SAP Mobile Experience community page and click ‚Äúfollow‚Äù. We‚Äôll be publishing more informative blog posts.

entry.title: Re: Can We restrict users for reprint of Billing Document...
entry.content:
SAP does not provide a standard configuration to restrict reprinting of billing documents. Once a billing document is posted and output is triggered, users with access to VF02/VF03 or the corresponding Fiori apps can reprint unless explicitly controlled.

The recommended approach would be to use Output Management with Status Tracking. SAP Output Management tracks whether an output has been printed. You can configure output determination to allow only one print per output type and prevent reprint unless status is reset manual. This is done via BRF+ rules and output parameter determination.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Create Cross-Company Code Purchasing across...
entry.content:
Hello @MadhusudanRedy 

You are encountering error 06166, which states 'Please only use plants with local currency' because the purchase order (PO) header's company code and currency USA1/USD do not correspond with those of the plant GBA1/GBP.

A purchase order can only be designated for plants whose local currency matches the company code specified in the PO header; otherwise, error 06166 will be triggered.

Check this SAP KBA SAP Support Portal-1800200 - 06166 Create PO from a Company Code to a Plant maintained in another Co Code with Different Curr - SAP ERP & SAP S/4HANA

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: SII tip for Spain #5: SII Adjustments for Canary Islands October 2025
entry.content:
Hi @CelalettinAktrk 

The Notes will create the necessary adjustments in SII to support the new Regimes 18 and 20, and the AIEM and the calculation of the new <TotalAIEM> tag.

If AIEM is applicable for you, you should enable AIEM first (check  SII tip for Spain #5B: SII Adjustments for Canary Islands October 2025 - Enabling AIEM) and create the new tax codes accordingly with input/output IGIC + AIEM where applicable.

The notes will also enable the new <ClaveRegimenEspecialOTrascendencia> 08, 18 and 20 as defined by the  Canary Islands Tax Agency. You need to run the customizing activity "Assign SII Attributes to Tax Codes for IGIC" accordingly to the new Tax Agency requirements (this might require new tax codes).

As I mentioned in the previous comment,  if you have to report special taxes, you can implement your logic in method SET_OUTPUT_DATA of BAdI EDOC_ADAPTOR to fill these fields since we are not providing any logic for them.

Regards

Francisco.

entry.title: Re: SAPUI5 Upload set with Table plugin send attachments...
entry.content:
Hi,

Working on similar functionality right now and here are my findings that might help you:

  1. UploadSetWithTable triggers file upload to uploadUrl right after you selected a file unless you do oEvent.preventDefault() on onBeforeInitiatingItemUpload/onBeforeUploadStarts
  2. You can't use async/await in onBeforeInitiatingItemUpload/onBeforeUploadStarts methods if you want to modify some things before upload starts with these two methods since original upload functionality will be triggered
  3. To trigger the upload of the files later you can get to FileUploader that is under the hood of UploadSetWithTable plugin and trigger them from it since it doesn't seem UploadSetWithTable has any kind of upload method
oEvent.getSource().getDefaultFileUploader().setHttpRequestMethod(sap.ui.unified.FileUploaderHttpRequestMethod.Put);
oEvent.getSource().getDefaultFileUploader().setUploadUrl(sUploadUrlPath);
oEvent.getSource().getDefaultFileUploader().upload()
  • oEvent.getSource() -> this is your UploadSetWithTable
  • sUploadUrlPath -> in case you are using cds with 'content @Core.MediaType' field annotation (or something similar) your upload url path should look like 'service/entity(ID)/content'.
  • You don't need to create any file binaries and pass them via requests. File Uploader already holds these files and as soon as upload is fired it will pass streams to the backend.

This is not the final solution but something already. Most probably there are much better and optimized ways to do the same thing. Not sure yet. If I find one I will share.

PS: I don't know why but file upload solutions in sapui5 are unnecessary complex as long as I remember.
